chunk_summary: Blood culture is the preferred diagnostic test for enteric fever, with highest yield in the first week of illness. Bone marrow culture is reserved for difficult cases. Supportive tests and imaging are problem-driven.
learning_objectives: Understand the role of blood culture as the primary diagnostic tool for enteric fever.
Identify the importance of early sampling and adequate blood volume for culture yield.
Recognize when to use bone marrow culture and supportive laboratory tests.
Learn the significance of antimicrobial susceptibility testing for Salmonella isolates.
key_facts: Blood culture yield is highest in the first week of illness and requires 5–10 mL in older children.
Bone marrow culture has the highest sensitivity and remains positive even after antibiotics.
Antimicrobial susceptibility testing, including MIC values, is critical for treatment decisions.
Supportive tests like CBC may show low leukocyte count with eosinopenia and mild transaminase elevation.
Imaging (e.g., abdominal ultrasound) is indicated for worsening abdominal symptoms.
reference_quote: Blood culture is the preferred diagnostic test for enteric fever and should be obtained before antibiotics whenever possible. (National Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases, India)
document_key_topics: Blood culture as the primary diagnostic tool
Bone marrow culture for difficult cases
